concepts.concept_name: Autotrophic nutrition and photosynthesis
Raw materials and conditions for photosynthesis
Stomata and leaf structure for photosynthesis
Other modes of nutrition in plants: parasitic, insectivorous, saprotrophic
Symbiotic relationships and nitrogen fixation

in_scope: Autotrophic nutrition: organisms that make their own food
Photosynthesis equation: carbon dioxide + water → glucose + oxygen
Role of chlorophyll and sunlight in photosynthesis
Leaf structure: stomata, guard cells, chloroplasts
Starch test using iodine to confirm photosynthesis
Parasitic plants: Cuscuta (amarbel)
Insectivorous plants: Venus flytrap, pitcher plant, sundew
Saprotrophic nutrition: fungi and mushrooms
Symbiosis: lichens (algae + fungi)
Nitrogen fixation by Rhizobium in legume root nodules
Replenishment of nutrients in the soil
out_of_scope: Light and dark reactions of photosynthesis — Introduced in Class 10
Calvin cycle details — Introduced in Class 11
Detailed biochemistry of nitrogen cycle — Introduced in Class 9
ATP and energy currency of cell — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Holozoic nutrition and steps of nutrition
Human digestive system organs and their functions
Digestion in the mouth, stomach, and small intestine
Absorption, assimilation, and egestion
Digestion in ruminants and amoeba

in_scope: Five steps: ingestion, digestion, absorption, assimilation, egestion
Human digestive system: mouth, oesophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine
Role of saliva and salivary amylase in mouth
Role of hydrochloric acid and pepsin in stomach
Role of bile juice, pancreatic juice, and intestinal juice in small intestine
Villi in small intestine for absorption
Liver and its role in digestion
Large intestine: water absorption and faeces formation
Digestion in ruminants: four-chambered stomach, cud chewing
Digestion in Amoeba: food vacuole, pseudopodia
out_of_scope: Enzyme specificity and lock-and-key model — Introduced in Class 10
Detailed biochemistry of digestion — Introduced in Class 10
Peristalsis mechanism in detail — Introduced in Class 10
Hormonal regulation of digestion — Introduced in Class 10

name: Weather, Climate and Adaptations of Animals to Climate

concepts.concept_name: Weather and climate: definitions and differences
Elements of weather and weather instruments
Climate and adaptation of animals in polar regions
Climate and adaptation of animals in tropical rainforests

in_scope: Weather: day-to-day atmospheric conditions at a place
Climate: average weather pattern over a long period (25+ years)
Elements of weather: temperature, humidity, rainfall, wind speed
Maximum and minimum thermometer
Recording daily weather and weather reports
Polar regions: extremely cold climate
Adaptations of polar bear: white fur, thick fat, wide paws
Adaptations of penguins: streamlined body, huddling
Migration in polar animals
Tropical rainforests: hot and humid climate
Adaptations: sensitive hearing, sharp eyesight, camouflage
Red-eyed frog, toucan, lion-tailed macaque, elephant adaptations
out_of_scope: Detailed climatology and weather patterns — Introduced in Class 9 Geography
Biomes classification in detail — Introduced in Class 9
Atmospheric pressure and wind systems — Introduced in Class 9
Evolutionary basis of adaptations — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Respiration as an energy-releasing process
Aerobic and anaerobic respiration
Breathing and the human respiratory system
Breathing in other animals

in_scope: Respiration: breakdown of food to release energy
Difference between breathing and respiration
Aerobic respiration: glucose + oxygen → carbon dioxide + water + energy
Anaerobic respiration: glucose → alcohol/lactic acid + energy (without oxygen)
Anaerobic respiration in yeast (fermentation)
Muscle cramps due to lactic acid build-up
Human respiratory system: nostrils, nasal cavity, trachea, bronchi, lungs, diaphragm
Mechanism of breathing: inhalation and exhalation
Rate of breathing increases during exercise
Breathing in earthworm: through moist skin
Breathing in fish: through gills
Breathing in insects: through spiracles and tracheae
Breathing in frogs: through lungs and moist skin
out_of_scope: Cellular respiration details and Krebs cycle — Introduced in Class 10
Gas exchange at alveolar level in detail — Introduced in Class 10
ATP production mechanism — Introduced in Class 10
Respiratory volumes and capacities — Introduced in Class 11

concepts.concept_name: Circulatory system: blood, blood vessels, and heart
Blood components and their functions
Heartbeat, pulse rate, and blood pressure
Excretory system in humans
Transport of water and nutrients in plants

in_scope: Blood: fluid connective tissue that transports substances
Components of blood: plasma, RBC, WBC, platelets
RBC contain haemoglobin that carries oxygen
WBC fight germs and infections
Platelets help in blood clotting
Blood vessels: arteries, veins, capillaries
Heart: four chambers (two atria, two ventricles)
Heartbeat and pulse rate
Stethoscope to hear heartbeat
Excretory system: kidneys, ureters, urinary bladder, urethra
Kidneys filter blood and produce urine
Dialysis (basic idea)
Transport of water in plants through xylem
Transport of food in plants through phloem
Transpiration and its role in water transport
out_of_scope: Double circulation and heart valves — Introduced in Class 10
Blood groups and transfusion — Introduced in Class 9
Nephron structure and urine formation — Introduced in Class 10
Root pressure and transpiration pull in detail — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Modes of reproduction: sexual and asexual
Asexual reproduction: vegetative propagation, budding, fragmentation, spore formation
Parts of a flower and sexual reproduction
Pollination: self-pollination and cross-pollination
Fertilisation, seed formation, and seed dispersal

in_scope: Asexual reproduction: single parent, no fusion of gametes
Vegetative propagation: stem (rose), leaf (bryophyllum), root (dahlia)
Budding in yeast and hydra
Fragmentation in spirogyra
Spore formation in ferns and mushrooms
Parts of a flower: sepals, petals, stamens (anther + filament), pistil (stigma + style + ovary)
Unisexual flowers (papaya, watermelon) and bisexual flowers (mustard, hibiscus)
Pollination: transfer of pollen from anther to stigma
Self-pollination and cross-pollination
Agents of pollination: wind, water, insects, animals
Fertilisation: fusion of male and female gametes
Seed formation: ovule becomes seed, ovary becomes fruit
Seed dispersal by wind, water, animals, explosion
out_of_scope: Double fertilisation — Introduced in Class 10
Pollen tube growth details — Introduced in Class 10
Tissue culture and cloning — Introduced in Class 10
Meiosis and gamete formation — Introduced in Class 10

concepts.concept_name: Forest ecosystem: layers and biodiversity
Role of forests in maintaining ecological balance
Food chains, food webs, and nutrient cycling
Deforestation, its effects, and conservation

in_scope: Forest layers: canopy, understory, forest floor
Crown of trees and its role
Biodiversity in a forest ecosystem
Forests as habitat for wildlife
Forests maintain water cycle and regulate climate
Forests prevent soil erosion and floods
Forests purify air: absorb CO2 and release O2
Decomposers: recycle nutrients from dead matter into soil
Food chains and food webs in a forest
Producers, consumers, and decomposers
Deforestation: clearing of forests
Effects of deforestation: soil erosion, floods, loss of biodiversity, global warming
Conservation of forests: afforestation, sustainable practices
out_of_scope: Ecological pyramids and energy flow quantification — Introduced in Class 10
Trophic levels in detail — Introduced in Class 10
Biogeochemical cycles in detail — Introduced in Class 9
Forest types classification — Introduced in Class 9 Geography
